Situation1: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A congregant has just passed away and the family needs him to officiate the funeral service very soon.
Story: The shrill ring of my phone cut through the clatter of tools in my hands. I was elbow-deep in the main production unit, sweat beading on my brow as I traced the source of the sensor errors that had halted the line for half an hour. The plant manager hovered nearby, his voice tight with urgency—every minute of downtime cost the company dearly, and I was the only one who could get things running again. As I reached for a replacement part, my phone buzzed again. This time, it was the synagogue president. “Rabbi, I’m so sorry to tell you—Mrs. Feldman just passed. The family needs you to lead the funeral as soon as possible.” My heart clenched. I could hear the grief in his voice, feel the weight of my responsibility to comfort and guide the bereaved. But the hum of the silent machines behind me reminded me of the other world that needed me, too. I stood frozen, torn between the wrench in my hand and the prayer book in my heart, knowing that whatever I chose, someone would be left waiting.
